FRAjdZsMMmzPSbNv3Cyw2w.text: Would give it six stars if I could. I have been there five or six times over the last five or six years, mostly when it was Bartolattas. Has always been some perv, and our most recent visit May 20 was no exception.  The setting in the outdoor cabanas by the reflecting pool is wonderful. The food and service are always impeccable. It is a little pricey, but if you'll pardon the cliche, sometimes you get what you pay for.

bosex1QBjFCFVMCmPiIjHw.text: We arrived early and were seated near the kitchen. Never good. The waiter gave us the wine list and brought his display of fish. So far, OK not great. We decided on fish for three of the four of us and specifically asked for the sauce with NO OLIVES.  Our appetizers were just average. (ravioli and antipasto). The meal was prepared tableside and after mine was served I realized it had olives. It took several minutes to get the waiter's attention to tell him of the error. He apologized, and I should have sent it back.  The entire fish dish tasted like olives. They gave us a few chocolates after dinner as an apology for the error. They should have comped my meal. There are many great restaurants in Vegas. This is not one of them.

m1asJzrgeCKGQXwUBHmOYQ.text: Overpromise, under deliver... That should be the motto of this place. The concierge Wendy highly recommended this place and would not stop talking about it. We had a few dietary restrictions and they went above and beyond to promise the sun, moon and stars to us. We were super stoked until it took 1.5 hours for our main course to arrive and the $32 bowl of pasta looked like it was something I could have cooked up in a college dorm room. Flavorless and utterly underwhelming. The risotto was ok for being uncooked. You would think an hour and a half would've been enough time to cook risotto. The pasta was just so awful it ruined the whole meal. The bartender put salt in our cocktail and over salted the food so much that my hands are swollen today and my entire body is bloated. To top it off, the someone at the restaurant stole our credit card number to buy something on Walmart.com and we had to cancel our card. Moral of the story is that there's a billion places to eat in Vegas, so don't let the concierge talk you into this one.

kht6HRnhMVNkBzh-wArP_g.text: meh  That's about all I have to say.  First off, this place is loud as hell since it's open tables and they are all pretty close together.  For starters, they cart this refrigerated fish display thing over to you and tell you what they have available. I dunno, but for me that wasn't so interesting because I was wondering what was going to happen to those poor fish in the display. Did they die for no reason just to get thrown away as unfit for cooking??? Poor fishies. =(  So with three people, the waiter suggested some sort of sampler thing. We were like, ok sounds good. Then we somehow ended up with bottled water and some bottle of crazy red wine. Of course there's no prices on the menu, but since I wasn't paying and was told not to worry about the price.....bottoms up!!!!!!  Each of the entrees were pretty sparse, and honestly I don't even remember anything good about them. The only thing I recall is thinking, holy crap if I was paying for this then I'd be pissed because this stuff is pretty bland. Plus I was starving, and when they bring a small amount of food at a time, it really doesn't hit the spot. It's more like a teaser that makes you scared that each thing is the last. And sure enough, the last thing came and I was still hungry. Even the dessert was meh, some sort of ice cream things and some bland chocolate cake thing.  They have a lot of waitstaff, but it's almost impersonal since none of them really know what you ordered or what is going on specifically at your table. Almost a kind of high end clusterfuck. And somewhat slow service too, when we were barely 2/3 done a party at the next table was done and gone (and they were seated after we were!!)  So we ended up knocking off two bottles of wine as well and the bill came to like around 700 bucks. OMFG pretty horrible since I was neither impressed, drunk, nor full.  Sadly, if I had been the one spending 700 and trying to impress someone, it would have been an epic fail. Good thing this wasn't the case!  So yeah, if you are trying to show off to someone, maybe somewhere else would be a better idea. Like In-n-Out would probably do a better job and you could even buy your date 5 In-n-Out tshirts and all kind of goodies and save like 400 dollars. =D

c4KXpCou6HBOgfKp2z2_hw.text: Lost our reservation and snooty about seating us at 9:15 even though there were many open tables. Disappointing.

-ffDKVLvlkB2zTwvATqvRA.text: From the time we walked through the door until the end of our meal it was an absolute over the top dining experience.  The food was beyond excellent.  From the chef's to the waiters to the wine pairings was like no other.  Their entire staff is so friendly and very personable.  We'll be back over & over again!! Best dish was the Ravioli, Mediterranian Sea Bass, risotto just to name a few.

dq6x-tAg7FkDVW9arOHGjA.text: Came here about 2 months ago but i was not a yelper then    Wow! What a bust. I had very high expectations for this place.   Started with the appetizer recommended by Bobby Flay. That was really good. All of the shellfish lived up to the expectations along with great flavor.  Then ordered what they called the best shrimp in the world. It was not even close to being the best shrimp. It was 30 bucks per shrimp. Even if it was 3 bucks I can still tell you it was weak.   Then ordered a fish called branzino from the cart of fresh seafood that they roll up to your table. They charged me 120 bucks for the fish and it did not taste like fresh fish. Maybe refresh.  What a rip off!   Some restaurants are good at making feel satisfied after they rip you off. This place did not come close.

SewrucsxuVNYyB6ed7NFcQ.text: What a fantastic experience !!! I went to this restaurant for my birthday to have the tasting menu and I am glad I did !!! Food was spectacular truly Italian seafood, they just remodel the place and I like the style very elegant and warm at the same time, service was outstanding our waiter Antonio was superb and made my birthday experience exceed all my exceptions.  Thanks Bartolotta for a fantastic dinner I will definitively come back !!!

-vJcdk23RGn7HmBl4aBUgg.text: This is a stunningly beautiful restaurant, no doubt about it.  And Chef Paul Bartolotta has deservedly won praise (and two James Beard Awards) for his brilliant cuisine.  So why only 3.5 stars (rounded up to 4) stars instead of five?  Well, it's simple.  That's what it deserved.  The Wynn advertises that, "Bragging about award-winning chefs is one thing.  Having them cook your dinner is another."  Now that certainly implies, at least, that Chef Bartolotta is himself present in the kitchen during dinner.  I don't know if he was or not.  But what I do know is that a) Chef Bartolotta is supposed to be a genius with seafood; b) he gets virtually all of his seafood flown in directly from Italy; and that c) his speciality is cooking the whole fish, filleting it tableside, and serving it for two.  This is a restaurant we looked forward to dining in . . .  There were seven us, celebrating a friend's birthday.  We each ordered appetizers, and the plates went flying around the table!  Apps included Seared Sea Scallops with Porcini Mushrooms appetizer was outstanding, as was the Warm Parmigiano-Reggiano Custard with Wild Mushrooms and Brussel Sprout Leaves and the Silky Duck Liver Mousse with Black Truffle.    Speaking of truffles, Italian white truffles were in but were advertised on the menu as begin available with *any* dish for $85.00 extra.    Uh, no.  Pasta courses included (among others) Lasagnette of Pasta, Lobster, Shrimp, Crab, White Wine, and Tomato; Gnocchi with Tomato sauce, Butter and Parmigiano-Reggiano; and the Linguine with Clams, White Wine, Rapini, Garlic, and Parsley.  All very, very good -- though *not* as good as, say, the pasta courses at Quince in San Francisco.  For the whole fish, Lynn and I had the San Pietro (aka John Dory), and while the flavors were delicious, the fish was overcooked and dry.    Now, in all honesty, my guess is that it was an simply an off-night in terms of the overcooked fish.   At nearly $1150 for seven of us (not including tip) a bargain, this place is not, but I'd be willing to come back . . . even quicker if someone else picks up the tab!

evTJlf6sDJv-4UibL6IICw.text: My wife and I had an excellent meal here while visiting LV for a convention.  The food was delicious, 4-star+ quality, the service was great, it was just SOOOOO over-priced I have to knock it down to Earth.  Our meal consisted of:  -A delicious ravioli appetizer- (5 or 6 pieces) -An Arugula / Pancetta salad (tiny) -A turbot (like a sole)- flown in from the Mediterranean, shared for 2.  This fishy cost us about $150, so it flew on business class for sure. -A shared dessert (it was delicious) -2 glasses of wine  Total (with tip)- just over $300  The meal was great- top to bottom, but every item was relatively acceptable to small in size, and simply super expensive.  I can't say I won't ever return, because the food truly was great, however the value is suspect and it would be much easier for me to return if I had a comp from the casino!

1rVFIWTQjwdKrDt1_U9lgQ.text: I am shocked at the horrible reviews. After living in Italy for 8 years, I have spent the last 13 looking for octopus salad and this was the only restaurant I have found so far that has it.   I knew this establishment was authentic when the sommelier (or I guess the "waiter # 1" most people are referring to...) and the very helpful, informative waiter spoke to me in Italian. After much conversation, I learned that the waiter was from Milan and has served at several other reputable restaurants in NYC and the sommelier was a young woman from Rome.  We had the $140 pp prix fix and I found it to be a great deal. The fish is flown in from Italy daily, and in fact, I haven't had seafood cooked and taste like this since my last time in Sicily. This is the real deal.  We started with the 4 appetizers. The scallops on the porcini mushrooms was heaven. Porcini mushrooms are very rare and difficult to find in the US and I was EXTREMELY impressed to find them fresh cut paired with this dish. Usually in the U.S. they can only be found dried!  The octopus salad was also very delicious but I have to admit I prefer the one in Italy because it's served as a real salad, not just paired with potatoes. The clams were very delicious, full of flavor. Our last appetizer, the arugola salad was very yummy and light - perfect pairing.  Our main course consisted of seafood risotto, pasta, and ravioli. I could instantly taste that the ravioli used hand-made dough - which was also impressive. The risotto was cooked to perfection and the pasta was al dente. Everything was perfect.  Finally we had our second course which was the fish. I was impressed with the generous serving and also the side dishes of the zucchini and onion&tomato topping on the fish. The contrast of the vegetables with the clean, fresh taste of the fish was amazing.  And finally, the three desserts, which made our neighbors very envious, was also rich in flavor and delicious. I especially enjoyed the home made gelato & sorbet trio combo as well as the panacotta with berries...  All in all, one of the best Italian restaurants I have been to in the United States and I can't wait to try Bartolotta's sister restaurant, San Domenico in NYC soon...

v1ow5iQlFcQMSA-_EMkMyw.text: The food was good but the service was diatant and at times kind of arrogant. I feel that the dinning experience should be better pairing the food quality with the service. Will not go back due to the service, talked to the management which seem not to care as well. It is sad because the food was really good.

hC4Noh4i1L39lTiDthbKHA.text: A great disappointment  .  .  .an arrogant server. .  .  We allowed 75 minutes for dinner before the show, La Reve, started  .  .  .  Our main course was served 15 minutes before show time.  Expensive and my least favorite meal after years of great eating in Las Vegas.

uH8ooq7hde_TlcdvDbwnSQ.text: Well. I have to say I saw this place on TV and thought we would give it a try . Upon arrival we were told new chef but it's as good as it was ! Well 600.00 later and I was beyond disappointed !! The only good thing was the wine !! Lobster was chalky, fish was eh, (160.00) btw- and over all subpar. Service is great, hence the second star, but go elsewhere.  I am feeling taken advantage of , not a good thing. :( For this price I would expect to be wowed, but not so much. Shame being I heard this place was amazing... Pass !!

-AMhXTpMNA8DPU5cvPQQdw.text: This was by far the most memorable dining experience of my life. The wait staff and sommolier truly knew their stuff and took excellent care of us.  I dined here quite some time ago and so do not remember all of the exact details, but I recall that we had the Loup de Mer fresh from the mediterranean and various pastas and salads. We paired wines with every course essentially and went all out. It was insane.  We ordered 4 of the desserts; however, the one I wanted the most (and it WAS my birthday) was the vanilla fig semifreddo- which we had not selected. Upon consuming all 4 desserts, I mandated that we must try this one also and I can honestly say no dessert has ever lived up to it. Although, last night's dessert at Tilth in Seattle came close!  Totally worth the large bill and an absolutely stunning restaurant. Having fine dined at many top restaurants, I am not sure why the ratings are not higher. I went again a second time and was just as impressed.

ex71a64fkKGK3arh85Xxcw.text: As a die-hard Milwaukeean staying at the Wynn, I had to try out the in house Bartolotta's restaurant, considering I didn't know they were a Milwaukee export.  I did not get the full experience at this place mainly because I am not someone that eats seafood (it is flown in fresh from the Mediterranean everyday).  I think that is a little ridiculous, but considering there are no fish in the desert, I don't blame them.  So, this relegated me to a few pasta dishes and some pancetta.  The pancetta was tough and fatty, but I expected that.  Could have been better though.  The sheep's milk ravioli was delicious, but the spaghetti with ragu could have been better.  Overall, not that impressed for the price,but I didn't eat outside.  That could have made the experience cooler.  The should take Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro in Milwaukee and stick it in the Wynn, in my humble opinion.

ayR44_MP5jEhNiAox4JALA.text: The best Italian food in the city in my opinion. Get the ravioli - it's pretty spectacular. Sit at the bar if you're alone and really want to soak up the experience. Ask for Rich, you will not be disappointed - he'll treat you like family.

BRUbVuNqvQvv6KOCMYF-Gg.text: Overpricing brings this restaurant down to three star territory, even though service was almost spectacular.  Their website shows a great outdoor visual pool that is stunning.  Note:  You will not be sitting anywhere near that pool.  Nobody was. I don't know why.  It was 8pm and about 85 outside, but everyone was seated inside.  Outside..like their website pictures show...was off limits. We asked. Not an option.  We looked at the empty tables through curtains.  The food was perfect.  The appetizer fried med fish was spectacular.  The appetizer rags of pasta with crab, lobster etc.. and the appetizer shrimp ravioli would have been star attractions as main courses.  However, no main course portions of these dishes was offered.  They want you to eat the almost unpriced fish.  We were directed away by our waiter from the John Dory to another white fish, since my petite date was done after the app pasta.  The white fish that had obviously flown first class from Maranello was moist, delicately flavored, but nothing special.  One plate $115. For unspectacular fish.  Otherwise, we had two cocktails, bread, two great fish appetizers and two great  pasta appetizers for about $130. Not bad for Vegas, and worth it.  Throw the forgettable hunk of whitefish on the tab, and it was $245!  Really, the fish was good, but on par with tourist traps in SF's Fisherman's Wharf district.  I'll pick Aliotto's anyday over this fish.  We were not informed of the price of our fish until the bill came.  The menu said $15 per 3oz.  I eat about a half pound of fish regularly. I guess pricing was before skinning and de-boning, which they did at the table. Nice touch.  Skip the fish.  Really.  Order appetizers like they are tapas, and this is a great place.  If you get sucked in on the fish, you will get robbed.  You might as well tell some kid in New Orleans "where they got them shoes" for $100.  You'll get more entertainment value.

aYW9ys1zurRO7RfnbmSbiA.text: OMG!! OMG!! OMG!!! Request a cabana table!!!!!!   Order the seafood stew or risotto!  **was a huge menu of pastas, seafood, steaks...anything your heart desires....they'll have it!** A bottle of Toscano red Some chocolate gelato for dessert Rejoice! You're alive....and...dining at BARTOLOTTA!!  An absolutely perfect meal/evening!!

vwMjrUU0yKtv688zTDD6Tg.text: It was late in the evening when we arrived in Las Vegas for a break from the real world, and decided to have a late dinner at Bartolotta. At 10:00pm, the restaurant was still busy, but were able to seat us immediately. and were quick to get us drinks to rinse the trail dust from out throats.  After a careful review of the menu, I ordered the duck liver mousse with truffles, and the "rags" of pasta with lobster, crab and shrimp. My wife ordered a frisee salad, and the vegetable risotto. My mousse and pasta were extremely good, but my wife was somewhat disappointed in the risotto. On our last visit, she had the seafood risotto, and found the vegetable risotto a little dull with a one note flavour of cheese.  Service was extremely good, and the fish cart is fun to review, but unfortunately none of the dishes on the cart can be ordered for one.

jDOyeiTfq2TRq4V9j3AIBw.text: After saving my pretty pennies for a while, and waiting for the right occasion (in this case, my home-girls from the MIA coming in for a weekend of reverie), I went to Bartolotta expecting the world and then some. SIGH. Where do I begin??   We ordered a bottle of Prosecco to ease into the night. As we were raising our hands in the air for our first toast, my friend found something brown floating in her glass. EEW... but, no worries -- we are in Bartolotta! The waiter will surely apologize and bring us another bottle... right?? Wrong. Instead, he found her another glass and poured some Prosecco into her glass and off he went... not to be seen much for the rest of night.   Because their prize on the menu is the fresh imported whole fish, we opted to go with appetizers and save room for the bronzino, which was bought whole to the table in a fish cart. While I totally can appreciate this Euro-tradition, I also appreciate that others do not. And, let's be honest, I'm not into seeing fish eyes right before I partake. Anyways, on the menu, it read $15 per 100 grams... Harmless, right?? Sorry folks. Each portion (which require min of 2 people), works out to be about $75. At least the waiter offered to give us a 3 person size (as opposed to the 5 person size) fish. But at $200 for a 3 person portion... DAMN GINA!!!   The apps we ordered were delish -- the octopus salad was scrumptious, as was the brussel custard that my girl ordered. Thus the reason for the 2 stars (and not 1)   And finally, the bronzino.... our bad waiter made a brief reappearance and cut the fish so unevenly that some of us got HUGE portions while others got slivers of fish. The fish was great... but it was seeped in oil! Before I would put it in my mouth, I would blot the sides of the plate to get rid of excess! I still can't be sure if it was the fish that was oily or if it was the sides (pan sauteed zucchini; a tomato basil mix; and roasted potatoes) but an oil sauce in your plate is gross.   All in all, my pretty pennies were wasted on Bartolotta. The ambiance is so-so; the service is terrible; and the food is mediocre (with the apps and wines being the stars).   My recommendation: save your $$ and go to any of the other fantastic seafood restos in town.

_zawjv7jMqCuMx-ETR6XTQ.text: I really liked this restaurant.  I believe that I need to start many of my reviews with the disclaimer that I tried "the tasting menu"   and I found it to be excellent........ravioli with black truffles were out of this world,    sardine olive paste amazing, prawns were great.......fish was fresh, service was excellent (especially the sommelier)  i thought the pacing of the tasting was too fast, it was more of a family style tasting, so you felt hurried, and the entree was just one fish, which was amazing but it didnt end with a bang....instead you felt a little stuffed, and trying to finish your last bites, tastings should be a gradual enjoyment of the menu.  I will come back.......but will try some others first

llfCak6m1oFjCnUskbeECQ.text: Wow. Unexpected best meal so far on this trip. Charming ambience, fresh seafood flown in from Italian waters prepared exquisitely. Our waiter Carlos was a wonderful guide on this culinary adventure! Que bella

p3R2bHosSST2Or3s5OUWMA.text: Absolutely the worst dining experience and an embarrassment to the Michelin star family! I would consider myself a connoisseur in fine dining while in Vegas and thought this would be a great opportunity for our group to try.. Unfortunately, everything from the loud and crowded tables.. The rushed poor service... the under cooked raw rice which they passed as Risotto and the burned Bronzini which they paired with the watery sauces.. Our group if six was extremely disappointed with this restaurant and won't return anytime soon... Yes, I've dined at many  Michelin star restaurants this definitely missed the mark.. Save your time there are many other delicious dining experiences in Vegas!

pFm99JPxO1QgZvY9Bqwe3A.text: Full disclosure upfront: I did not pay a cent for this meal, as people that invited me were were mega-guests of the casino host.  That being said, I believe our bill was approx $170/pp.   Atmosphere = 5 stars, big time! When I heard we were sitting outside along the lagoon, I about fainted b/c the temps were 109 that day, cooling to a nice 98 in evening.  "You asked for this table?", I wondered.  But (see disclosure above) my job was to shut up and be grateful!  Much to my delight, they actually AIR-CONDITION THE OUTSIDE, making it a wonderful, peaceful, cozy dining experience, with each table having its own canopied cabana.  (Sorry, energy-saver geeks... just one other reason to be appalled by Vegas.)  Food & Wine = 4 stars. Beautiful & simple presentations, high-quality, simple & fresh ingredients, portions are moderate.  Considering how $$$ the menu was, the wines were surprisingly value-priced.  If you know your Italian wines (hard to go wrong if you like dry, mineral-y whites anyway), then you'll be as happy as a porcca in merda.  Menu = 1 star, for extreme over-complication. So they price fish by the gram, most around $15/100 grams.  Good thing There's An App For That, b/c who can figure that out?!  (BTW, 1 oz = 28.35 gr, so you want about 170g of fish for a standard 6oz serving.)  Ok, so I get we're messed up here in the US & don't use the metric system, but seriously, that's just unnecessary.  Plus, then it makes suggestions about how many ounces are suggested per person... thereby going schizo on standards of measurement.  To make this even stupider, you're bound to pay for whatever size whole fish (b/c you have to buy the whole thing) the kitchen has available, so it's not just enough that you decide you want 650g of san pietro, b/c then the server has to go check w/ the kitchen to see if they have something like that even in stock.  WTF?  After 20 mins of straining over the menu (and we were all sober, mind you), we agreed to just close up & have the waiter order for us.  Everything was delicious, but I'd think twice before coming back here b/c of the kooky menu hassle.

F7e7-NOCG4ZZv5f49FnHjg.text: I have never experienced a meal where I had something to eat, in this case the Langoustines, and after taking a bite of the food and then taking a sip of wine that the mixture of the two transformed completely into a third taste altogether.  In this case, 1 +1 truly equalled 3.  The food was excellent, service perfect.  Yes.  It is pricey.  By the time the two of us walked out, our bill with excellent wines was nearly four digits in size.  For us, this was well worth the price.  Thank you!

lybnNV0wMPzutKI3WXzdEQ.text: Absolutely fabulous. We always sit at the bar with Richard. Service is 5 stars. The house salad is perfect to start, then the mix fried fish apps, always two different pastas. We always try something different when we come. Then the brazino with cruda & the lamb. We always get the gelato and sorbets. The wines are a must with the pairing of each dish. The bar to me is the best table in the house. You never know who you will meet there.

XTj1KrN0mQ7g0yL_FATRrg.text: One of the best Italian dinners I've had in Vegas. The interior is just gorgeous and clean and the food and atmosphere is marvelous. Their lamb ($50) was the best! Seafood and meats were very fresh and so were the vegetables. Everything was prepared professionally.

dcD3Jcj3CcQy_J2i__HG7w.text: Had a nice birthday dinner with my wife. This is a beautiful restaurant. The pastas were perfection - we sampled a few, and each was unique and amazing. And dessert was really great. The only issue was that our server got caught up with a large group and we were sort of forgotten about near the end of the meal - he didn't bring the coffee we ordered with desert and was clearly distracted. Other than that small issue, it was a really nice dinner and I absolutely recommend.

agoz5gQvy6FbPJlT_dWnfg.text: Wynn/Encore Appetizer Crawl: Part 1  When you get to be my advanced age you don't do bar crawls. Instead you do appetizer crawls. It's easier on the system and takes far less recovery time. With the wife and a couple friends in tow, we decided to check out some of the Wynn/Encore restaurants. Bartolotta was our first stop.  We grabbed some seats at the bar, ordered some drinks and looked over the menu. We got two orders of the lasagnette con ragu di crostacei. It was recently featured on the Food Network as one of Bobby Flay's favorite appetizers. Now, I'm not a Flay fan, but the dish did sound delicious -- pasta, lobster, crab, shrimp, white wine and tomatoes. While it isn't one of the best dishes I've ever had, it was very good with large chunks of lobster and crab and a light, fresh profile overall.  They were nice enough the split the orders so we each had our own plate. The bartenders were friendly and accommodating and didn't mind that we only stuck around for a drink and one order. They did verify that the fish is flown in fresh daily from Italy -- and yes, that expense is passed on to you. If you're looking for cheap seafood go to Red Lobster.

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. lasagnette con ragu di crostacei
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States

oBofsZ_BYPY_FwFrZqPWsg.text: Took my boo for her bday! Hands down the best seafood I have ever had!!! The good is so fresh you just have to try it to believe it!   Luciano is hands down the best server I have ever had! If you go, make sure you request to sit in his section! If it's not on the menu he will make it happen! He is extremely knowledgable, and will pick your dinner for you!!! We loved him so much he got a hug on the way out! Tell me last time you went to a restaurant and did that!!!!

dBwW0uv6lS9Ipc3aCBB-kQ.text: Delicious food and fantastic service. We came here on Christmas Eve. They had some screw up with our table so we had to wait at the bar for a drink. For this, I didn't give a 5 star. .  Rich who is the bartender was beyond accommodating and can make a delicious drink. My husband ordered a "cable car" and I had the Kir Royal to start. Both delicious. And he was just a delight.  We were then seated downstairs near the water with the most romantic view. It is just beautiful.  Our Italian waiter Luciano knew everything there was to know about food, especially fish. He was able to describe all the little differences between each fish that had jumped from the ocean and flown here just a day or so ago.   We had the artichoke salad with porcini mushrooms which was just mouth watering. Arugula was warm and porcini were delectable. Next we split a small portion of the seafood risotto. Outrageous. The little langoustine that was there was the sweetest fish I have ever tried. Lastly we had the Bronzino. He brought us 3 different sauces. Tomatoes with garlic, salmoroglio, and one with lots of anchovies.  One was better than the next.  One of the best meals we have ever had at a restaurant.

01YygSs-UWh_bIrYV6mgwA.text: I had dinner last night at this place and it wasn't worth the $400+ we spent just for two. The experience wasn't great from the start. From the host that said they didn't have tables available when the restaurant was barely full, to sitting down at the bar and dealing with a crowd of obnoxious group of people screaming, not chatting, behind your neck and laying on the same stool we were sitting at.  I felt like I was at some Irish pub. The bar tender wasn't bad, but he just didn't have common sense or touch.  The food was ok, nothing special. I would not even consider ever coming back here. Beware guys, you are just going to be treated like one of the bunch at some fast food chain.

Qfcfek1QR-yzvysGlKlAPw.text: The food was fine. As usual, the appetizers are better than most of the entrees. Expensive? Yes, but that doesn't matter if the food and service warrant it. However, in the case of Bartolotta, the service was horrible. We felt we were being served by a used car or timeshare salesman. This guy (Mario? Marcutio?) talked fast and kept the menu as confusing as possible resulting in a $350++ meal for two that did not include desserts and only a half bottle of wine since my husband was not drinking.   The fish is priced by the ounce and since we were ordering different entrees, we were concerned over the amount each of us would receive. This waiter Assured us he would size the portion to best suit US. Did not happen. Put the entire fish on the plate coming to a $90 entree that my husband couldn't finish! Also, I think the waiter got mad that neither of us got the truffle add-on and ignored us the rest of the night. We were not picky nor complainers. To celebrate our 25th Anniversary & my husband's birthday, we came out expecting to pay dearly for this meal, BUT we also expected to be treated extremely well and not offered "up sells" constantly. Not the "classy" experience they try to portray.   If Chef is "obsessed with making your experience as close as possible to dining at an Italian seaside villa" as another review stated, he failed miserably. I've been to Italy and was treated far better there than at Bartolotta's. We were VERY DISAPPOINTED and would like our money back! We wouldn't have tipped the head waiter, but there were other guys that attended to us as well who were very nice (and I think told to be quiet because they only spoke when spoken to) and we didn't want to stiff them.

mJ5iZMF45VzToneoNQKG_w.text: Chef Paul Bartolotta is obsessed with making your experience as close as possible to dining at an Italian seaside villa.  To do so, seafood is flown in from the Mediterranean.  Mushrooms he uses were plucked from Italian soil.  Several Yelpers noted their waiters spoke fluent Italian.  The waiter for our table was actually Latino and was fluent in Spanish. Close enough.  Try not to get piss drunk at the casino before coming here because you need to do math.  This restaurant sells their fish whole, priced by dollars per 100 grams. Divide that by the number of diners.   Also, it helps if you're dining with a cocaine dealer so he can explain what 100 grams of anything looks like.  It's no surprise that many Yelpers complained about being sucker punched by the bill.  Many reviewers also griped about the simplicity of the food.  For the cash you're spending, there are better places if you're on a Vegas safari for an artistic and innovative meal.  Bartolotta publicly admits he's not a creative chef.   His plating is slightly better than Olive Garden.  But close your eyes...this is not the garlicky, red-sauced, heavily-cheesed Italian food Americans are used to.  The dishes we tried were fresh, light, and uncomplicated.  Ingredients were kept to a minimum, serving to enhance instead of obscure.  Simple Italian seafood, cooked to delicious perfection.  Mouth, welcome to Sardinia.

5AFH2zcWs01gzLNCxFom3g.text: Great if you know how good what you're getting is... But if you think it's too pricey there's a great buffet as well...

7n2ac2w2FSNyELfdVRA-eQ.text: Follow your waitstAff's recommendations and let chef Paul do the rest' easily the best meal I've had in years!!!! Everything in your Sicilian dreams is here. We will return.

qHv156eOkyth3INzXnjKZA.text: Oh my goodness where do I even begin. If you love seafood you'll love this place.  The AMAZING grilled shrimp and vongole clams was the best I'd ever had. Nearing the end of our meal, we were prepared a whole fish (sea bass) in rock salt. It was filleted right before our eyes! I would give this restaurant a try if you are looking to have a rich seafood dinner in Vegas.

VRo4sYG5y-EGcrY2Fz6nDg.text: This was probably one of the nicest and best restaurants I've ever eaten at. The heart of celery, fennel w/dried freezed fish eggs, slivered was amazing. Best martini ever. Oh don't forget about the fish. Love how they prepare it right there at your table.  Probably the best, best dish was severed last and that was the dessert. So amazing. We had the sample dish. It got better after my brother in law took out his "BLACK" card. They brought us more stuff that wasn't even on the menu. My mouth was watering. Two wks later and I'm still talking  it!

tYFXfXCNOQixK2W7dSkSyA.text: There are a lot of reviews that are kind of all over the place.  This is a seafood restaurant, so let me just say that when I read less than stellar reviews by people who didn't order seafood, it irks me a bit.  This place does seafood great.  The presentations are not fancy and the emphasis is on the pristine freshness and quality of the ingredients.  This place is expensive.  Really expensive.  But the fish and shellfish are flown in every few days from Italy.  Where you gonna get that anyhow?  And in the middle of a desert?  Sure, it's gonna cost you.  We had the Bravo Top Chef tasting menu - this is their best tasting menu.  This is a lot of food.  Some of it was not that memorable but there were a few dishes that were crazy good.  I mean, so good that it stopped you in mid-chew.  You pause before taking the next bite because you want the flavor to linger in your mouth longer.  Nope, not even a sip of delicious wine will be allowed to disrupt the gentle decay of the sensation.  Enough of the poetic waxing.  Let's get down to it.  I'm going to go over my raves and then a few complaints.  The ravioli di ricotta con caciotta Toscana (sheep's milk ricotta cheese ravioli with pecorino and marsala wine glaze) is perhaps the most delicious pasta I've ever had.  This is one of the restaurant's signature dishes, and rightfully so. OMG.  The grilled rock lobster is case in point on how fresh ingredients, simply prepared, can be sublime.  Other highlights were the tiny soft shelled crab, the octopus salad, and the salt crusted snapper.  The service was in general very attentive.  The wine selection is large but pricey.  $80 for Santa Margherita pinot grigio?  Where do they think they are, Vegas?  ... Oops.  We did settle on a beautiful Chablis and a knockout Brunello di Montalcino.  My biggest complaint was with the bar.  I asked for an Aviation cocktail - a classic gin-based cocktail that is not obscure by any means.  The waiter came back and said the bartender didn't know what that was.  Huh?  Don't they have a recipe book back there?  So I used the cocktail app on my phone to give the waiter the recipe: gin, lemon juice, Luxardo maraschino liqueur, lemon twist.  Ok, that's weird.  At least they didn't ask me for any food recipes - I have an app for that too.  Then the waiter comes back to tell me that they did not have Luxardo maraschino liqueur.  What kind of high end Italian place doesn't have Luxardo maraschino liqueur?  So I ordered a martini.  They knew how to make that.  The bar issues and a few duds (bland risotto, boring seafood rigatoni, uninspiring desserts) brought my rating down to 4 stars.

lnBoPDgyP9nICD4NqTZ6pA.text: While in Vegas we decided to go out for one fancy dinner. Italian + seafood sounded awesome.  When we walked up to the hostess desk, all four women completely ignored us, then assisted the couple behind us and sat them at the bar to wait. When one girl finally looked reproachfully over and asked for our reservation she told us we'd have to wait, not offering the bar as an option.  As we were seated, over twenty minutes later, two waiters had a tiny amusing dispute over who would wait on us. They were both very nice. Skipping the wine list, we decided on mixed drinks, which were okay but not worth the price. The decor was fab, and I wanted to see the grotto area. The seafood risotto was good but I don't like my pasta al dente [is that how risotto should be? too nutty, ick], the chicken was tasty, and the seared beef had no flavor but was very tender and juicy.  It was amusing watching two guys get their fish carved up. Boy, I sure hope they enjoyed that expensive as heck fish.   Total we were there two hours, and when we left at 10.30 there was still a big line waiting to be seated. Overall, we weren't blown away by our choice for a fancy dinner, and definitely preferred our drunk night at In-N-Out.

6mNkqLgbkRYPKsu2iRXYjw.text: Very pricey establishment ( you are paying for the views and location) I had better italian food at my local family run restaurants, but overall the food was well prepared, the staff was knowledgeable, courteous  and eager to please  I had some kind of risotto - very good, I can make it better myself though

ziX-IrH9lr1uv_QrrssURA.text: Yummy Italian food. I always eat at least one dinner here during my stay at the Wynn. They have the best gnocchi. It is very small. I get 2 orders. I get the meat sauce pasta as well. I also enjoy  the veal chop or whatever steak they have that night. The steak usually comes with mashed potatoes and asparagus.

V4XUKimo_vnsOPCwqeYrjQ.text: Really wonderful service--impeccable.  Greated with earnest, smile.  Wait staff was on everything!  The food was really good.  The pasta is perfect   The fish was great.  Chicken? Not so much.  Will go again.

NdDrr5Zu9lGljuN28ZZ8pg.text: Extremely disappointing...Isaac was the best part of the evening. He genuinely smiled and served amazing truffle rolls.  The foos items were either not prepared correctly or maybe an off night.  Each item lacked any type of seasonings, freshness or flavor of any kind.  Grilled octopus over cooked and chewy.  Scallops lacked flavor and were not fresh. Polenta has a sauce that tastes like burned bitter liquid---inedible and that's when we spoke to the server.  The fish was not fresh and smelled bad.  Extremely overpriced for bad food.  Many other way better places to eat at the Wynn---La Cave being one and The Cafe being another.

z0kbdWpGkEL47kLTK443Bg.text: One of the best Italian restaurants I have been to, by far. We were running late to the Le Reve show which we had booked at the hotel (our fault) and we had reservations at the Costa di Mare. Typically the dining experience is at Costa di Mare is suppose to be 1-2 hour experience and I can understand why.  The beautiful outdoor seating has a coy pond and is so relaxing. Now we had to speed up this 2 hour experience into 30 minutes. I forgot our servers name but he was awesome and was able to make our experience the best with the short amount of time we had.  To start with, they brought olive bread with ricotta cheese and olive oil which was amazingly addicting.  As far as what we ordered, we left that up to the server (who was Italian). From what I remember we got:  Ravioli Di Ricotta Con Caciotta Toscana Maccheroni Alla Chitarra Al Ragu Toscano Gnocchi Di Patate Con Fonduta Di Pomodoro Insalatina di carciofi, porcini, ruchetta e pecorino  I have to say one of the best pastas I've ever had. I cannot wait to go back to Vegas to try this place again and have the chance to have the chance to have that 1-2 hour experience. Many thanks to our server, he made sure we were taken care of and recommended some awesome dishes!

9dYR57eaZLD4FPga8Mcwvw.text: I am sure their seafood dishes must be impressive, but I only had from their bar bites menu, which needs a complete rethinking. A dish billed as containing short ribs was essentially a breaded rice ball with some meat waved over it. I do regret I did not send it right back.

9ZrpZmB6OR4j2iEWzTDQJg.text: Delightful food and excellent service. Enjoy the black truffle rolls and the crab ravioli. Top notch restaurant. I will return.

l1zH0E-zpoOYl8j2fEIctQ.text: Me my mother and sister came here and it was such a great experience. The decor is beautiful with this huge fish chandler. The food was just as amazing we had ordered a lot of different pastas we loved the ravioli ricotta and the gnocchi were so creamy and delicious it was this taste of Italy meets elegance.

9ku-mC9ksVncFrH4ASVaDw.text: I had the tasting menu and a wine pairing.  I visited this restaurant previously before it was renamed and also recently now that its costa di mare.  Previously this restaurant was hands down 5 stars.  Today, the tasting menu was boring and bland. Too much of the food was overly charred. One plate was served piping hot. Even the bread was not great. The service was great though.  The food was very below average for what was a 700 dollar meal for 2 people.

iq3IgaJGk14aJJvJZXyY2A.text: This place is a gem in vegas I had a wonderful experience the foot was amazing and the staff was super friendly the place is beautiful at must see not to expensive but it was worded

VIHRxS6aq1WnSID9a8EC5g.text: They gave us the table in the corner, in front of the kitchen. There are many  table with the view of the lake but it not available for us ! The restaurant is empty. There are not ambience. The food is just good but not outstanding. The price is overcharged. I will not return to this restaurant !

fyWux1hd3mpwerv5-CXqYA.text: On our wedding night my husband and I are here. AMAZING. We did the tasting menu and holy heck was it a lot of food, but so amazing and fresh. Everything gets flown in from Italy every 48 hours. It's certainly not cheap, but you don't do if you can't afford to spend some $ and enjoy and beautiful, romantic dinner. It's worth it!!! Service was 5 star, explaining everything.  I see a bunch of negative reviews. You don't come here for random ravioli for $30. You come for the fresh seafood and wonderful service.

izTSAWUWfqnIigGa4BW57Q.text: Been wanting to eat here for quite a while and I finally got my chance on my last trip. It was much better than I expected. I ordered the "Gran Menu Di Mare" tasting menu, which was perfect sampling. Everything tasted great, but the langoustine set this meal apart from the others. My experience was excellent from the very start. Luciano and Andre made sure we had a nice experience. They made sure we were taken care of but didn't smother us either. It's not cheap to eat here, but it's worth every penny. Great food, great service and great atmosphere. What else can you ask for?

R3aSEOd3_3iouuMGNgxjoQ.text: Such an amazing meal, ambiance, and service. We sat outside near the pool in a cabana and it was a lovely dining experience. I am a pescatarian and people in my party we're vegan and there were tons of options and the food was amazing. Can't wait to come eat back here when I'm back in Vegas.

P_z7xBS2BpWYsZ1pOpm8Iw.text: This was probably the best meal I've ever enjoyed. Perfectly prepared scallops to start, fresh pasta for the second course, and beef fillet in a way me reduction for the entree.  This was the best steak I've ever eaten.  Impeccable service and elegant ambiance rounded off the meal.

XRHym5oQvmtwes5OepM5Tg.text: One of my absolute favorites! Yes, it's pricey but if you're willing to splurge, this is the place to do it! The decor is just beautiful and  the restaurant overlooks an outdoor pond (downstairs).  During our last visit, we ordered the octopus, which was probably the best I've ever had, and the gnocchi (amazing!) to start. My husband and I also shared a branzino (fish) with an anchovy sauce that is to die for! I could put that sauce on bread and have that as a meal. Seriously good stuff.  Before you order, they bring out a large rolling display with various raw fish and other seafood. Everything is SUPER fresh, less than 48 hrs from ocean to table. The serving of the cooked fish is quite a presentation. They bring it out, cooked whole, and separate the filets from the bones. It's served with simply cooked, but very delicious, zucchini and potatoes.  Expect to pay around $200 for two people (without alcohol). Great place to celebrate a special occasion!

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States

tryfmCfjukN6d1HgfUplEw.text: One of the finest restaurants at the Wynn Hotel. Absolutely stunning decor with gorgeous lagoon water view. The seafood is daily flown in from Italy and the exquisite taste and the preparation will not disappoint the most pickiest foodie. They are absolutely right about their langoustines, they are one of the best we ever had. Tagliatelle pasta with shrimp and lobster was excellent and Bronzino fish was very delicate but with lots of flavor deboned at your table side and accompanied with light citrus sauce. The drinks were strong enough but very tasty.  Panna cotta desert with berries was very light and a nice finish after diner. The complementary little cookies and amazing truffles were delivered with your check. Top notch all the way. The only negative which is a little deceiving is how they charge for the fish $16 for 100 grams on the menu  (who calculates how much it's going to cost...?) so it comes out about $120-$150 for an order. It is big enough for two people but still would be nice to know in advance. Expensive...yes, is it worth it... yes, but be prepare to spend about $350 for a couple. Service is 5 stars as always, it's like every server is  a college graduate with a major in customer service. Overall Great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VLcE-7TOAUeZd4pUpjT0oA.text: My family and I came here to celebrate a birthday. I'm a fan of al fresco dining but my sister isn't. Our table was by the window overlooking the pool/patio area...and I was wishing I were outside.  We were presented with a glass case on wheels with their fresh (and moving) seafood. Their seafood comes straight from Italy which may explain the prices. Of all nights not to be in the mood for seafood, I had to pick the night we went here. We got the lasagnette, gnocchi, pollo alla Riviera Ligure, filetto and brodetto di pesce (my bro-in-law got this but he doesn't like to share his food or have pics taken of his food so, I'll be skipping this). For dessert we got budino di cioccolato, zabaglione ghiacciato, granite and gelato.  Lasagnette con Ragu di Crostacei: Pasta sheets with shrimp, lobster, crab in white wine and tomato. Quite tasty and you can definitely taste fresh seafood. 4/5  Gnocchi di Patate con Fonduta di Pomodoro: Potato gnocchi in creamy tomato sauce with basil and Parmigiano-Reggiano. I love gnocchi and this had the perfect texture and consistency. The sauce was simple but amazing. 5/5  Pollo alla Riviera Ligure: Roast chicken with asparagus, artichokes, porcini, olives in lemon herb sauce. Perfectly cooked. Moist chicken quarters with crispy skin. Great sauce. 5/5  Filetto di manzo al Sangiovese: Seared beef filet with potato puree, carrots and rabe in red wine sauce. Tender and perfectly medium-rare. Not very flavorful and not worth $54. 3/5  Budino di Cioccolato e Banana, Gelato di Banana: Warm chocolate-banana custard and banana gelato. 4/5  Zabaglione Ghiacciato al Torrone al Cioccolata Amaro e Arancia: Frozen torrone sabayon, dark chocolate, orange and orange zest. There are two things I don't like combined with chocolate: mint and orange. I was not ersponsible for getting this and I did not like it. 2/5  Gelati & Granite: Pick 6 sorbet (black currant, lemon, mango, coconut, apricot, raspberry)/ gelato (vanilla, banana, espresso, gianduja, pistachio, amarena, rosemary, chocolate, nocciola, zabaglione, croccantini al cioccolato)/ granite (moscato, pineapple, blood orange, strawberry proseco) flavors.  For my 6, I chose banana, gianduja, nocciola and pistachio gelati +  moscato and strawberry proseco granite. I love everything I picked but my favorites were gianduja (chocolate and hazelnut), nocciola (hazelnut), moscato and strawberry proseco. 5/5  The bread service was unremarkable. We got complimentary petit fours after dinner and dessert: chocolates with caramel and tea inside.  Truffles are in season for a limited time at $90/dish (October-November...possibly early December). They have a dress code so, please don't come in casual wear.

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. &#34;Ber&#34; months = truffle season!
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. View from our table
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fresh seafood

_Jwhws_y-oIkRTs9xE65tQ.text: The GM of the restaurant personally emailed me and I ended up going back to the restaurant for dinner this past weekend. The food was amazing as it was last time, and the service was impeccable this time around. The ambiance was also very nice. Thanks for turning things around!

8RbgBpNAMb0IOeLz3LOBwQ.text: Hit or miss food with mostly impeccable service in the Wynn. We hit this place for dinner before heading to Le Reve when the SW could not seat us in time. The appetizers we ordered were excellent. The scallops were delicate and perfectly cooked. The langoustine was also delicious.  While the fish looked interesting but we are used to fresh seafood on the coast so flying it in every 48 hours was not overly impressive. It was probably our mistake to stray from their specialty. My wife got a mushroom pasta dish that was good but nothing spectacular. I got the filet which was also good but again nothing exceptional. The cut of meat itself was good but lacking flavor. The creamy polenta it was served on was rather bland and I couldn't help but be reminded of a Mexican plate covered in refried beans.   Service was excellent throughout except for one odd encounter. We thanked one guy for refilling our water multiple times. He told us it was his "passion." It came across as forced and a bit patronizing.   Overall there are lots of restaurants in Vegas charging a premium for overly hyped food and this one falls into that category for me. I don't mind paying the price for great food but I left this one feeling disappointed.

8JkiwdCcL48aOMTwg43ViQ.text: We came here for the valentines dinner and I had great service here. Server knew the menu, and special fish of the day very well and answered my questions with very friendly way.  We ordered couple of appetizer and whole snapper to share and we got full!!! Next time, I won't even eat lunch and try the tasting menu. And I am not dessert person but their ice cream and gelato was amazing (since I'm allergic to chocolate, I can't even try a lot of dessert)  and we will be coming back for sure!! I hope I can sit downstairs or outside next time

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious ice cream and gelato
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snapper whole fish. Server will deboned and plate in front of you. What a talent!!!
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Appetizers octopus and mussel dishes

sGHViQ5WYglrRyoqC69qhA.text: I had a lovely lunch here during a conference. Our servers were attentive and friendly, dutifully rushing out our dishes given that we had a very tight schedule. It's a nice space, down a dramatic marble staircase and facing an inner garden   The burrata with tomato and basil was fresh and beautifully presented, a very generous portion. The next cheesy buttery ravioli with a caramelized balsamic reduction on top was a show stopper. Rich, yet so flavorful. Again, a generous portion of six ravioli for this appetizer course. The Mediterranean seabass over a tomato stew was perfectly cooked.   The only thing that was odd was that the overhead lights kept turning on and off. Very bizarre.

8hbHBeCC06AKGA32aZGDsw.text: This place blew my mind. I LOVE seafood, and this place knows how to showcase the seafood so it sings. Be prepared to pay $$$ for the seafood though as it seems that most of it is flown in from the Mediterranean. If you can't stand to pay for your fish's flight across the Atlantic, get any one of the pastas - it's no stretch to say that they are comparable to some of the best pastas in Italy (IMO).   I had:  The saute di vongole to start: the sauce is what makes the difference in this dish (you'll hear this often in my review). Simple flavors of tomato, wine, seafood, basil, and garlic that go so so perfectly with the vongole. I had to ask for more bread to sop up the broth.   The maccheroni alla chitarra con ricci di mare for the primi course: this pasta is soooo good. Sea urchin, crab, tomato, lemon - the ingredients sound so decadent. However you taste the sea first, then the butteriness of the sea urchin and the sweetness of the crab. The tomato sauce with lemon cut the richness and add a brightness to the dish. I've had many uni pastas in my time but this takes the cake. It's well balanced. Rich but light, and it respects the animals of the sea so well.   This was over the top but the primi was so good! Garganelli freschi al ragu di crostacei for the secondi: another pasta and it's arguably better than the first. Red and blue shrimp, spider crab, lobster, white wine tomato in a garganelli pasta. It sounds like a huge mix of seafood but they were able to bring out each flavor so you could taste each one so well. The sauce was a tomato base but it tasted more like they took a little bit of the sea and put it in the sauce with some wine and hints of tomato. I can't say enough how this sauce just brought the whole dish together.   Pagaro (purple snapper) in a salmoriglio sauce. They serve the whole fish, so it's best to share this with at least 1 person (after the great bread and pasta you'll be almost full anyway). Each person gets a plate with roasted potatoes, steamed vegetables and the fish. The fish. The fish is simple so if you don't want to pay a ton of money ($16 per 100g. Our fish was 1kg. You get the idea) skip this part. For those of you willing to pay, the fish is delicate and quite beautiful to eat. Quite the treat!  Too full for dessert but I will go back and try it eventually.   Takeaways- on a budget? Order the pasta. You won't be sorry.   Want the full experience? They have a James beard degustation that looked quite impressive. At the very least, do a pasta then a fish to share.

qI8UbAeZaaHrU16Y3ExGJg.text: Please read ALL the negative reviews written about this restaurant very carefully, they are all True. I now wish I had done my homework before making our reservation. My dinner party and I had an absolute nightmare experience at this restaurant.  Absolute amateur hour at this place, the entire staff, including management would be better suited for working at a low-end cafe in the city of Barstow. The sommelier was lost and completely incompetent, I wouldn't give this bum a mop job.   We ended up walking out and going straight to another restaurant, enjoyed a fabulous dinner and the night was saved.    How the Wynn hotel management allows this type of restaurant to operate at their hotel is baffling to me. They must know it lowers the image of the Wynn brand.   PLEASE READ ALL THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS, THEY ARE ALL TRUE.   CONSIDER YOURSELF WARNED!

UKa0RRctU6aoGZ1_WSFA7A.text: Let me start by saying, we're locals. We came in for one reason only, the langoustine appetizer. We saw it on a best of, must try, list, and I couldn't have been more disappointed. It was small, limp, undercooked, under seasoned, and amounted to one small shrimp, cut in half, for $30.00. Shame on you, I know better but most folks that dine there probably don't... Charging $30 for that poor excuse of a crustacean is practically highway robbery. Never again.

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pathetic.

-kOdrtjNQSHJUIqhU4JjLQ.text: Vegan ravioli was excellent. Dish is seasoned well and sauce was balanced perfectly. Sole fish was fresh, melts in your mouth. Ricotta cheese/ olive oil served with bread is great. Deserts were awesome. A meal we wont forget about.

e3WfcbEeH1RWtyw4BTXXLA.text: Came here to celebrate my 4th anniversary. We were happy to get in with last minute reservations, and the ambiance was romantic and great. They also gave us complimentary dessert in honor of our anniversary and the food was delicious. The positives stop there. Our waiter rarely came in to check in on us, and we could not get his attention to pay and get out. We had to wait 20-30minutes just to get our check, even when we're clearly not eating or touching our food. In fact, we did not even order from our waiter, another gentleman must have sensed our eagerness to order, as he took our orders and relayed the message to our actual waiter.  For someplace as high class as this, I expected to be waited on a bit more than we were. It actually felt as though they weren't paying attention to us because we were younger than other guests.  Disappointed with the experience

cWJa4sNgGzcT-FpUvmcU4Q.text: I'm thinking all of the good reviews were for the previous restaurant because I was very dissatisfied with the food tonight. I don't mind paying for quality but to pay for mediocrity makes me angry especially after a $180.00 meal that leaves me hungry. I like lobster so I decided to get the rock lobster spaghetti.  I thought I would like it so much I got the entree which was $60.00 . The only thing I ate on the plate was the four small pieces of lobster  and two bites of noodles. The lobster peices were good but the sauce was pure generic super market grade . We also ordered a salad for $20.00 that came with like 8 spinach leaves, 10 peices of tomatoes, and 4 cheese balls. It was on a plate a little bigger than a saucer. My brother in law ordered the fish that looked blah...he said there was no taste. It looked like cafeteria food . The waiter asked them how they liked the fish he recommended they said it was ok with most of the plate was untouched.  When I  go to an expensive restaurant I expect the food to be creative, delicious and have the wait staff on top of things. We also waited a long time for the entrees. We would have been better off going to Bahama Breeze! I think they should put their heads together and rework their menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This was the bill for 5 people.
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. They gave us some sweets with the coffee  We passed on their $14.00 desserts.
Photo of Costa di Mare - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rock lobster spaghetti. .. not worth  $60.00

OLy_CB6NvAXKIBUfS2HRSg.text: Seafood flown in daily from Italy. This place is amazing. Service and atmosphere amazing. Langoustines are delicious and not easy to come by on many menus. This is a definite splurge  restaurant.

IqFjj0grUqWTr7rQJm_WGA.text: Nice setting and very good service.  The food was very good although the portions were too small for the price.  A Branzino for two at $160 served two very small portions.  The sole although not from Dover was very nice.  I would recommend this seafood restaurant for anyone who enjoys good fresh fish.

qh0MVbUpuuKbk9blEW-BdQ.text: This was one of the most disappointing meals we've had. Maybe it was an off night based on other rave reviews, but we had a terrible experience. Though the atmosphere was very nice. Not super friendly at the hostess desk. It took a long time for our server(s) to come to our table.  Finally served water and given menus. We ordered several appetizers and a main dish.  Our bread server, Isaac, was the best, and the truffle rolls were delicious. Unfortunately, it was down hill after that. The grilled octopus was over cooked. The scallop dish lacked flavor. Actually all the dishes lacked flavor and we just didn't taste fresh ingredients. The polenta with truffle sauce was awful, the sauce tasted bitter and over salted, it was actually in edible. We sent it back. Finally the baked pasta came. As soon as our server cut into the foil that encased the dish, we got a terrible smell of bad fish! There were no herbs present in the sauce; we tasted 1 clam and it was bad. At this point we complained to our server who was visibly disappointed and felt bad, he told the manager who also apologized. They took the dishes we complained about off the bill. One final comment, we felt this restaurant was completely over priced! There are many other restaurants at the Wynn that are wonderful! Try Allegro or La Cave.

KEgPJhbMASZdH-1YorAH1w.text: Book a reservation at this place for my wife's birthday and I can honestly say that it was a major mistake. For a supposedly a top notch restaurant, this restaurant can't even beat a cafe standard diner. Not sure if it's because we are Asian or the place was busy but its just sad that they can't seem to comprehend basic dining service yet alone fine dining.  Waiter that just stop by and say are we ready to order?? Not bother to introduce himself. And when we asked for any special, he proceeded just to show the paper on the table that I guess he put there cos he don't bother to spiel.   My wife would like an extra truffle bread and the busser that apparently seems only able to speak Spanish said yes and never deliver.  When our appetizers arrived, a $45 langoustine and a $27 octopus. The server or back server doesn't even seem to bother to check back. A simple 2 minutes 2'bites check up. Major flaw. My wife was so mad that we don't even bother to wait for the main course. Asked for manager who thankfully understand our frustration. Maybe because he is an Asian too.  He apologize profusely and very professionally asked if he can book us another reservation at other restaurant since it's late. Although I don't mind paying for the appetizers that we ate, he proceeded by taking care of the check. But hey, don't let my review stop you for eating here. Maybe just an off night for them or just because we live in a world of "racial profiling" these days. But honestly there should be no such thing in this world yet alone hospitality industry. Definitely wont be back.  Thanks costa di mare for ruining my wife's birthday dinner.

nbmbfFYCb8-9l7d9iKNWrQ.text: First of all. Beautiful surroundings! The service was excellent, the seafood was fresh and the wine selection was on point.

y76z9S8EiutPBAB7-BuqyQ.text: Really poor and far too expensive. One tiny langostino for $40-four small bites. Fish entree was bland. Cooked with no spices. Sauces served on the side and were cold. Service was EXTREMELY slow. We told them we needed to leave in 2 hours when we sat down. An hour later we only had bread. They served our dinner 5 minutes before we had to leave for a show. The bill was wrong by $40 (too high). Just bad. The one good thing was the ink pasta appetizer.

xxHJkH1neHbWXJVxLa_TsA.text: Messed the orders.  Didn't get close to the food we ordered.  Overpriced for the gamble on this place.

u_SmIRCVWmQo8ymd3ziWIQ.text: The food is delicious, we had jumbo scampi they are so delicious, but very small and pricy $40 each. We also ordered the lobster pasta which 8s average, and the sea food pasta which is so amazing.

HXZpd0yhc3ioN7o67lH8aA.text: We tried this place on a whim at our stay at the Wynn to see Jerry Seinfeld and oh am I happy we did. I can still remember the details of the meal even today and we enjoyed this meal almost a month ago now. We had no idea what to order, so we just took the waiter's suggestion and ordered the chef's tasting menu. I'm happy we took the plunge because everything was just superb. It started with fresh bread and a little taste of soup. It then continued to appetizer (4 total), pasta course (3 total), then main course (1 to share), and finished off with two full desserts and gelato and sorbet tastings. Out of everything I would say the ribbon pasta was my absolute favorite along with the octopus appetizer. I've never had tender octopus in my life. It is so notorious for being chewy...but definitely not here. The waiters were all so accommodating and kind. I was so lost in the food that I forgot to take pictures. If we return in the future, I definitely will get my phone out.

WjDHnlYZMSPRTi_KMW6vBg.text: Costa di Mare is a hidden gem in Vegas. The atmosphere, service, and unbelievable food all are worth raving about. Maurizio treated my group so well and recommended the most amazing dishes, all while being respectful to our dietary restrictions. Can't wait to come back.

Bf8qec_wnUwiUFwbNTgLUA.text: The seafood at this restaurant literally had me speechless. What a beautiful dining room with a view of its own lagoon. The fine dining atmosphere can be romantic as well. The menu is a little intimidating with all the Italian names but ignore those and read the descriptions ;D  This restaurant is the ONLY restaurant in the ENTIRE North America that serves Langoustines. They were cooked so perfectly and had a texture that tasted like if crab and shrimp had a baby. So delicious and was the highlight of my dinner. I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS!  A few other must have dishes: - Ricotta Ravioli (ravioli di ricotta con caciotta Toscana) - Grilled Octopus (polipo Ligure alla griglia) - Ricotta Butter that comes with bread for the table (Seriously, you have to try it, its so good)
